title: 2021 CMIMC Integration Bee Problem 1
text:
$$\int_0^5 \max(2x, x^2)\ dx.$$  
Proposed by Connor Gordon.
solution:
I was dumb in the exam and could not understand I was making graphs and then I don't know what was I doing The main thing is to integrate $2x$ from $0$ to $2$ and $x^2$ from $2$ to $5$ 
 
 Therefore $\frac{117}{3}+4=\boxed{43}$

title: 2021 CMIMC Integration Bee Problem 2
text:
Text: $$\int\frac{\ln^2(x)}{x}\ dx.$$  
Proposed by Connor Gordon.
solution:
The u substitution to employ here is $u = \ln(x)$ giving us $du = \frac{1}{x} dx$ Using this we get 
 $$\int u^2 du$$ This simply evaluates to 
 $$\frac{u^3}{3} + C$$ Finally eliminating the u parameter we get 
 $$\boxed{\frac{\ln^3(x)}{3} + C}$$

title: 2021 CMIMC Integration Bee Problem 3
solution:
By trigonometric identities $\sin^2(x) \sin(2x) = 2\sin^3(x)\cos(x)$ 
 Therefore our integral is 
 $$\int_0^{\frac{\pi}{2}} 2\sin^3(x)\cos(x)$$ which can be evaluated with the substitution $u = \sin(x)$ to be $\frac{\sin^4(x)}{2}$ 
 Therefore $$\int_0^{\frac{\pi}{2}} 2\sin^3(x)\cos(x) = \frac{\sin^4(x)}{2} \Big|_0^{\frac{\pi}{2}} = \frac{1}{2}$$

title: 2021 CMIMC Integration Bee Problem 4
solution:
From a grader's perspective (spoiler contains the answer) The answer to this problem was $\dfrac{4591}{30}$ 
 
 We got the following correct answers Correct Answers wrote 4591/30 68+(2551/30) 153 1/30 86+2432/30 336/30 65/6 665/6+211/5 This last answer came with a kind little note saying "I am NOT going to add this > )" 
 We also received the following incorrect answers Incorrect Answers wrote 11/30 16871/105 185 75 152 + 19/30 3847/30 4291/30 153 17/60 591/5 152 1/30 154 + 19/30 
 Please be kind to your graders~ 
 
 Hint The terms do factor nicely into only two terms Further hint Look at this in terms of $(x + 1)$

title: 2022 Integration Bee Problem 3
text:
\[\int_0^1 x\sqrt[4]{1 - x}\ \mathrm{d}x.\]  
Proposed by Connor Gordon.
solution: sol \begin{align*}\int_0^1 x\sqrt[4]{1 x}\ \mathrm dx &= \int_0^1 x^1 (1 x)^{\frac{1}{4}}\mathrm dx\\ &= \frac{\Gamma(2)\Gamma(\frac{5}{4})}{\Gamma(2 + \frac{5}{4})} = \frac{1! \cdot \Gamma(\frac{5}{4})}{\frac{9}{4} \cdot \frac{5}{4} \cdot \Gamma(\frac{5}{4})} \\ &= \boxed{\frac{16}{45}} \end{align*}

title: 2022 Integration Bee Problem 4
solution: Integration by Parts Let $u=\log(x) \text{d}v=x^{\frac{1}{2}}\text{d}x$ so that $\text{d}u=\tfrac{1}{x}\text{d}x$ and $v=\tfrac{2}{3}x^{\frac{3}{2}} $ Then $$ \frac{2}{3}x^{\frac{3}{2}}\log(x) \int \log(x)x^{\frac{1}{2}} \text{d}x = \int \frac{2}{3}x^{\frac{1}{2}}\text{d}x$$ $$ \implies \int \log(x)x^{\frac{1}{2}} = \frac{2}{3}x^{\frac{3}{2}}\log(x) \frac{4}{9}x^{\frac{3}{2}} $$ Evaluating at the bounds of integration gives $\boxed{ \tfrac{4}{9}} $

title: 2023 Integration Bee Problem 1
text:
\[\int_2^0 x^2+3\ \mathrm dx.\]  
Proposed by Connor Gordon.
solution: Let's try a few of these For this one the antiderivative is just $\frac{1}{3}x^3+3x$ The only tricky part is that the integral's bounds are backwards so the result is $ \left(\frac{1}{3} \cdot 2^3 + 3 \cdot 2\right) = \frac{26}{3}$

title: 2023 Integration Bee Problem 2
text:
\[\int_0^1 \frac{1}{x+\sqrt x}\ \mathrm dx.\]  
Proposed by Connor Gordon.
solution: sol We let $u=\sqrt{x}$ so $du=\frac{1}{2\sqrt{x}} dx$ Then the integral is $$\displaystyle\int_0^1 \frac{1}{u^2+u} (2u)du=\displaystyle\int_0^1\frac{2}{u+1}du $$ The antiderivative is obviously $2\log(u+1)=2\log(\sqrt{x}+1)$ but this is an indefinite integral so the integral is equal to $2\log(2) \lim_{n\rightarrow 0} 2\log(\sqrt{n}+1)=\boxed{2\log(2)}$

title: 2023 Integration Bee Problem 3
solution:
Write this into $\int_{0}^{\frac{\pi}{4}}\frac{\cos(x)}{\sqrt{\sin(x)}}dx$ 
 
 $u=\sin(x)$ and integrate leads to $\boxed{2^{\frac{3}{4}}}$

title: 2023 Integration Bee Problem 4
text:
\[\int_0^\infty x e^{ \sqrt[3]{x}}\ \mathrm dx.\]  
Proposed by Connor Gordon.
solution: $u^3=x$ then integration by parts and get $\boxed{360}$

title: 2024 Integration Bee Problem 1
solution: sol $\frac{\log(x^{2024})}{x}=2024\cdot\frac{\log(x)}{x}$ and $\frac{d}{dx}(\log(x))^2=2\log(x)\cdot\frac{1}{x}$ so $\int \frac{\log(x^{2024})}{x} \mathrm dx=1012\log(x)^2$ so the answer is $\boxed{1012}$

title: 2024 Integration Bee Problem 2
text: \[\int_0^2 |\sin(\pi x)|+|\cos(\pi x)|\mathrm dx.\] Proposed by Anagh Sangavarapu.
solution:
Since the graphs of $\sin(x)$ and $\cos(x)$ are just horizontal translations of each other and both of them have a period of $2\pi $ it follows that 
 \begin{align*}
\int_0^2 |\cos(\pi x)| \text{d}x = \int_0^2 |\sin(\pi x)| \text{d}x \end{align*} Therefore we wish to compute 
 \begin{align*}
\int_0^2 (|\sin(\pi x)|+|\cos(\pi x)|) \text{d}x &= \int_0^2 (|\sin(\pi x)|+|\sin(\pi x)|) \text{d}x \\
&= \int_0^2 2|\sin(\pi x)| \\
&= 2\int_0^2 |\sin(\pi x)| \end{align*} Then note that $\sin(\pi x)>0$ for $0<x<1$ and $\sin(\pi x)<0$ for $1<x<2 $ so we have 
 \begin{align*}
2\int_0^2 |\sin(\pi x)| &= 2\int_0^1 |\sin(\pi x)| + 2\int_1^2 |\sin(\pi x)| \\
&= 2\int_0^1 \sin(\pi x) 2\int_1^2 \sin(\pi x) \\
&= 2\left[ \frac{\cos(\pi x)}{\pi} \Big|_0^1\right] 2\left[ \frac{\cos(\pi x)}{\pi}\Big|_1^2\right] \\
&= 2\left[ \frac{\cos(\pi)}{\pi}+\frac{\cos(0)}{\pi}\right] 2\left[ \frac{\cos(2\pi)}{\pi}+\frac{\cos(\pi)}{\pi}\right] \\
&= 2\left[\frac{1}{\pi}+\frac{1}{\pi}\right] 2\left[ \frac{1}{\pi}+\left( \frac{1}{\pi}\right)\right] \\
&= 2 \cdot \frac{2}{\pi} 2 \cdot \left( \frac{1}{\pi} \frac{1}{\pi}\right) \\
&= \frac{4}{\pi} 2\cdot\left( \frac{2}{\pi}\right) \\
&= \frac{4}{\pi} \left( \frac{4}{\pi}\right)\\
&= \frac{4}{\pi} + \frac{4}{\pi} \\
&= \boxed{\frac{8}{\pi}} \end{align*} $\square$

title: 2024 Integration Bee Problem 3
text: \[\int_0^1 \frac{\log(x)}{\sqrt x}\mathrm dx.\] Proposed by Robert Trosten.
solution:
We proceed with integration by parts Let $$u=\log(x) \text{d}v=\frac{1}{\sqrt{x}} $$ Then it follows that $$\text{d}u=\frac{1}{x} \ \text{d}x v=2\sqrt{x} $$ 
 Thus we have 
 \begin{align*}
\int_0^1 \frac{\log(x)}{\sqrt x} \ \text{d}x &= \int_0^1 u \ \text{d}v \\
&= uv \Big|_0^1 \int_0^1 v \ \text{d}u \\
&= 2\log(x)\sqrt{x}\Big|_0^1 \int_0^1 2\sqrt{x} \cdot \frac{1}{x} \ \text{d}x \end{align*} Note that 
 $$\lim_{x \to 0} 2\log(x)\sqrt{x} = 0 $$ so we have 
 \begin{align*}
2\log(x)\sqrt{x}\Big|_0^1 \int_0^1 2\sqrt{x} \cdot \frac{1}{x} \ \text{d}x &= 2\log(1)\sqrt{1} \lim_{x \to 0}2\log(x)\sqrt{x} \int_0^1 \frac{2}{\sqrt{x}} \ \text{d}x \\
&= 2\cdot0\cdot1 0 \left[4\sqrt{x}\Big|_0^1\right] \\
&= 0 (4\sqrt{1} 4\sqrt{0}) \\
&= 4\cdot1+4\cdot0 \\
&= 4 + 0 \\
&= \boxed{ 4} \end{align*} $\square$
